infor.name: your paying for pensions per month
infor.message:
Employee contribution

Enter the regular monthly amount you pay into your pension.

If you do not contribute, leave this blank.

infor.name: your employee paying for pensions per month
infor.message:
Employer contribution

Enter the regular monthly amount your employer pays into your pension.

If your employer does not contribute, leave this blank.

infor.name: one off lumpsum
infor.message:
Lump sum payment

Enter a lump-sum amount to find out how that may affect your pension benefit.

You usually get tax relief when you pay into a pension scheme.

However, you will usually have to pay tax if you pay in more than Â£40,000 in a single year.

infor.name: income you want to live
infor.message:
Target income

Enter the annual income amount that you think you will need to maintain your desired lifestyle when you retire.

infor.name: Age you want to retire
infor.message:
Retirement age

You cannot claim your state pension until you reach the State Pension age determined by the government. However, occupational and personal pensions can be started at any time from age 55 onwards.

The age at which you choose to start your pensions has a significant impact on the amount of money you will receive.

If you retire early, there will be less money in your pension pot and you will receive a smaller pension.

This calculator does not include State Pension.

infor.name: tax free cash
infor.message:
Tax free cash

You can take up to 25% of your pension pot as a tax free lump sum.

This is capped at 25% of the current LTA (Lifetime Allowance) determined by the government. Anything above that will be taxed at your normal rate.

If your pension pot exceeds the current LTA value, your cash lump sum will be capped accordingly in this modeller.

infor.message: Select the percentage relating to the estimated annual growth of your fund.

infor.name: annual charge information
infor.message:
Change the percentage to match the charges you are paying on your current pension(s).

The charges you pay have a direct impact on your fund.
